history.content: You will be fine.  They go over the devices for about a month in 143.  I will say though if you take the two simultaneously the device portion of 143 will be a breeze.  I will recommend though to take 105 & 120 as your first EE courses unless you are absolutely sure you wish to become a device physicist/MEMS/fab person.

You will be fine.  I will say though if you take the two simultaneously the device portion of 143 will be a breeze.  I will recommend though to take 105 & 120 as your first EE courses unless you are absolutely sure you wish to become a device physicist/MEMS/fab person.

You will be fine.  I will say though if you take the two simultaneously the device portion of 143 will be a breeze.  I will recommend though to take 105 & 120 as your first EE courses unless you are absolutely sure you wish to become a device physicist/MEMs/fab person.
You will be fine.  I will say though if you take the two simultaneously the device portion of 143 will be a breeze.

children.subject: The timings are all accurate yes.  I would however take 130 instead of 143, since its information will be extremely useful for many future classes (105, 143 in particular).  For you however, I'd highly recommend taking Pister's MEMS (147) class over both 130/143- it also delves into a good deal about fabrication (since the MEMS cantilevers have to be built after all).  120, 105, 147/130 would be a good combo time wise imo- you'll always be busy, but will still have time to enjoy the weekends (and I've commented multiple times before on how to cut the 105 work time).
Thanks for taking the time to help me out, I really appreciate it!

I'm actually thinking of taking 105, 120 and 143 next semester. Just those classes no other GE's or decals. I really have no idea which subfield of EE I want to specialize in, 105 and 120 seem like fun and they are useful for many of the other upper divs and since high school, I've always been absolutely fascinated with semiconductor fab and MEMS fab. I think those classes will help me narrow down with subfield I enjoy the most.

Do you think that will be too much, in one semester? Per the HKN website, EECS101, and talking to people, it looks like I'd be committing about:

1. 10-15 hrs per week outside of class for 105

2. 10-15 hrs per week outside of class for 120

3. 5-10 hrs per week outside of class for 143 until the last few lab reports which will take a tremendous amount of time.

Is that accurate?

history.content:
> unless you are absolutely sure you wish to become a device physicist/MEMS/fab person.

Which would be an awesome, rewarding, and fulfilling career path! :)

I'm a transfer student and I took the Equivalent of Physics 7a, b, and c, Math 54 and Chem 1A and 1AL equivalent. While at Cal I've done CS61A and 61C, EE16A and 16B and I'm taking CS70 over the summer.

Will I be prepared enough for EE143? Or is EE130 a must before taking 143?

I've seen various posts about 143, but I couldn't find anything specifically related to 130 before 143. If I missed another thread about this topic can you please link it below.

Thanks for your help!
history.subject: EE 143 Without 130
